name: heptadecanoic acid, methyl ester
Reason: The basic structure to consider is that of pentadecane, which is a hydrocarbon with 15 carbon atoms and has a melting point around -10°C. First, the carboxylic acid methyl ester functional group typically raises the melting point due to polar interactions and ester linkage, compared to the hydrocarbon chain. The polarity of the ester functional group allows for dipole-dipole interactions that increase the melting point. The ester can be estimated to increase the melting point by around 40°C. Secondly, the addition of two carbon atoms in the chain (from pentadecane to heptadecanoic acid methyl ester) can slightly raise the melting point due to the increased Van der Waals forces, estimated at around 2°C per carbon atom. Hence, the estimated increment due to the additional carbons would be 4°C. Combining these two effects gives us a predicted melting point of 34°C.
